If you've worked for at least a year you will qualify for unemployment benefits.
You do go, you go to your state, every state has an office of employment security and that's where you sign up.
You, depending on the state you may have a waiting period.
Unemployment benefit is 26 weeks.

Well you have to, but you have to show that your looking for work, so you have to report to your unemployment office with some periodicity, maybe weekly, in some states it may be more, you know, monthly.
They generally ask you to keep a record, so you have to say, I went to this establishment, I interviewed.
They also, these departments of employment services tend to have job registers, so they may ask you, have you got out on a job register?

Now they may not tend to be as strict as they might be, because they don't have a lot of people to follow up with people, but the intention in giving you unemployment benefits is not just to give you a paid vacation.

So let's talk about severance.
It's different from unemployment.
Severance is something that your job may or may not give you.
What are the circumstances in general under which you will get severance.
It really depends if you're a long-term employee and it's a mass layoff, they're laying off 500, 600 people.
You might get so many dollars or so many weeks of pay for the number of weeks that you worked there, so if you worked there 10 years you may get 10 or 20, some multiple of 10 weeks.
But it really depends on the company.
And if a company is doing layoffs because they are in bad shape, they might not.
My advice to people is just to always ask and always negotiate.
Make sure that you're in negotiating mode.
Negotiate other things as well.
Large companies, you might be able to negotiate the date that you leave.
You want to make sure you know what's going to happen with your accumulated sick and vacation pay.
Can you take that, how much of that are you going to be able to keep and how much of it goes away.
You might want to negotiate things like whether or not you can keep your email and for how long, so that you can at least send out emails letting people know, you know, where you are.
Some companies provide you with outplacement services.
Usually these are larger companies but when you are given that pink slip, basically ask for - ask for the moon.
You are probably not going to get it, but ask.
Be clear, the company doesn't owe you anything, but no company wants to feel, especially with longer term employees, that they are not being compassionate.
So rely on human resources to perhaps offer you a compassion option by asking for what you need.

Let's turn to the emotional side of things.
In order to keep up your strength for going out and going on job interviews which is not always easy, what are some tips people can follow?
Well first of all, stay upbeat.
It's the easier said than done, but look at the other people who are in a similar situation.
Thank God for you health and for the things you do have.
As I said negotiate the best terms you can have and network, network, network.
Find a group of people that maybe similarly situated so you all can talk about tips and plans.
Put together a schedule.
The worst thing that happens is some unemployed people, Farai, is they are unemployed so they don't do anything.
They get up, they have their breakfast, they start watching TV, you know.
The day sort of goes by.
Well, you know, one day a week make sure that you're out having lunch with a friend or a colleague, preferable a colleague so you can dress up in your work clothes and pretend your going to work.
Volunteer.
If you can't find work at least volunteer with people who might be helpful to you.
Even think about creating your own internship.
Go out on informational interviews.
Do whatever you can to keep yourself positive, and don't - understand that you are not your economics.
A line that I've had with people - use with people a long time.
When people are unemployed they are down.
Here's why.
We spend, you know most of us, eight to 10, some 12 hours a day on their jobs.
The United States was celebrating its bicentennial, and nobody had yet seen a movie called ""Star Wars.
Many people's social relationships are rooted in their jobs.
So if you are part of a unit of 10 or 12 people and two are gone, yeah, 10 go on and they are feeling bad too.
They may have survivors' guilt, but you have to be willing and able to understand how big of an impact this job had on your life.
Some of the people you worked with were not your friends, they were your associates, get over it.
Some of them are friends and you will have plenty to talk to them about even though you are not working with them, but the point is to keep yourself fully engaged.
What about communities?
You know, if, several people lose their job on one block or dozens of people have lost their jobs in a neighborhood what can happen?
Well, it's a morale buster to see other people around you losing their jobs.
To see - and it also is an economic strain on communities.
People start borrowing from each other.
Think about a family where two or three people lose jobs.
Immediately those people have jobs think, I've got to help my brother, my sister out, and that creates some kinds of tensions.
When do you get repaid?
How are your economics?
So, this joblessness is not an individual thing it really does affect communities, families, churches, neighborhoods.
People have an impulse to help, the first one in a group that gets laid off, but when you look up and half the group or a third of the group is laid off it really becomes something of a strain.

People however, can really work through this by offering to barter some of their skills and talents, helping their friends or working with friends who may have small businesses where they might help them out a day a week, or so.
So, people can be very creative and get through - push through the challenge.
If, you've just been unemployed and your sister-in-law and neighbor have small children and is dealing with daycare maybe you can offer to do that a couple of days a week.
What about budgeting?
When you don't know necessarily how long you'll be out of work.
How can you budget?
Well, it's very difficult.
What you have to - one of the old rules of thumb and it's very old I think the number is different now.
But the old rule of thumb was for every 10,000 dollars a year you were earning it would take you about a month to find another job.
So, 50,000 a year would be five months to find work.
So, if you use that, as a rule of thumb you've got to start looking at your resources.
And the first thing to do is just cut everything out that's discretionary.
You know, no extra dinners out, no, I feel so bad I am going to go shopping.
No - your whole family has to get involved in - OK, until we understand our economics better we are cutting back and it's got to be a firm thing.
There are free things to do, especially in the summer but basically if, there's a pink slip in the household the entirety of the budget has to change until there's some sense of what's going on.
Look at your savings - see how far they're going to stretch.
What's your plan with your investments, with your mortgage?
All of those things you've got to start thinking about.
How will I pay?
How will I stay even?
And if you're going to have to go in the hole, and often people do.
People borrow, they use credit cards, they use other things - try to use the least costly option.
But when you first get a pink slip it shouldn't be - OK, how am I going to borrow?
It's going to be how many months?
How much money do I have to survive how many months?
And if those unemployment checks are 300 dollars a week and you use to bring home a, 1,000 dollars a week, that's pretty significant.
It means a lot of things are going to have to cut back.
